The Signal

Trump's war on Antifa

Donald Trump blames the far left for the US riots, and white supremacists have been gearing up online, excited by the notion of a race war. So where does that leave the majority of peaceful protesters?

World

  1. Live: Crowd numbers surge near White House with less than an hour until curfew

    Protest numbers are building again in Washington DC, despite the National Guard and police cracking down on protesters with tear gas and stun grenades yesterday. A city-wide curfew begins in less than an hour. Follow live.

  2. Austria will transform Hitler's birthplace into a police station

    After decades of debate, the house where Nazi leader Adolf Hitler was born will finally be turned into a police station, a move the Austrian Government described as "neutralising" the space.

  3. I dread looking at the phone each morning. I'm scared to see what happened overnight in America

    It has been like this for more than two months now, the news from home has made being away hard to bear, writes Zach Gardner.

  4. White flags are appearing across Guatemala — but coronavirus infection isn't to blame

    It's midday in Villa Nueva and Leidy is standing on by a highway with her two-year-old son Leiton, waving a white flag at peak hour traffic. It's an act of last resort.

Asia Pacific

  1. UK warns China to pull back from Hong Kong

    The United Kingdom warns Beijing to step back from the brink over an "authoritarian" national security law in Hong Kong that risks destroying one of the jewels of Asia's economy.

  2. Experts call for Australia to snub Europe, US in favour of Asia post-coronavirus

    Australia should work with partners in Asia rather than the US or UK to rebuild the global economy in the wake of coronavirus, a group of experts says.

  3. Hong Kong police deny Tiananmen Square vigil for first time in 30 years

    For the first time in 30 years, Hong Kong police have denied an application to stage a candlelight vigil marking the anniversary of China's 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown, because of coronavirus restrictions.

  4. New app for backpackers called Backpicker hopes to improve farm labour shortages

    A former farm and mining worker hopes his new app will help ease labour shortages in Victoria's north-west.

Business

  1. Aussie dollar surges above 68.9 US cents, as Wall Street jumps on COVID-19 recovery hopes

    The local currency jumps to its highest level since mid-January, and today's GDP figures will reveal how much the summer bushfires and coronavirus impacted Australia's economy.

  2. Why is Australia's dollar surging even while the economy hurtles towards recession?

    Australia's currency has risen sharply against the greenback, even as the nation hurtles towards its first recession in nearly three decades. Why?

  3. GDP figures are due out today, but what does it all mean for you?

    It's not just an abstract idea. What happens with today's figures could directly affect you in a number of ways.

  4. How lessons learned during the Great Depression made one company coronavirus proof

    When the Australian General Disinfectant Company was founded in 1933, the Great Depression was in full swing. Its chairman says it owes its continued survival to innovation and local supply chains.

Sport

  1. Analysis: Hate him or hate him, Lance Armstrong's contradictions make for a compelling story

    Nothing Lance Armstrong can say will ever make people forget how he defrauded the sporting public, but decades after the height of his success, the American still presents an intriguing study of a complexly flawed, fallen sporting hero, writes Simon Smale.

  2. Two champion Lions teammates inducted into Australian Football Hall of Fame

    Simon Black and Jonathan Brown, both key pillars of the Brisbane Lions' three-peat of AFL premierships and club legends, are inducted into Australian Football Hall of Fame.

  3. FIFA president says players protesting George Floyd's death deserve 'applause, not punishment'

    Gianni Infantino says football leagues should apply "common sense" and support players protesting the killing of George Floyd, and that their actions "deserve an applause and not a punishment".

  4. Australia proposes quarantine 'bubble' for Rugby Championship

    The entire Rugby Championship may be hosted in Australia if the competition goes ahead this year, while plans for a four-Test Bledisloe Cup series are also being discussed.

Arts & Culture

  1. The best films to stream in June, selected by our reviewers

    From independent to festival favourites, classics, and underrated films from the vault, our writers scan subscription and free services and report back with their picks.

  2. From a floating Egyptian tomb in the heart of London, to wrapping Germany's parliament, these are some of Christo's greatest works

    Christo, the Bulgarian-born artist best known for his temporary installations based on wrapping the exteriors of landmark buildings, dies at age 84 of natural causes at his home in New York City.

  3. Melbourne's live music venues could 'disappear en masse' when government help stops

    In Australia's music capital, there are glimmers of hope for the return of live music. But it'll be drastically different and more expensive, and industry is warning beloved venues will close forever unless governments step in.

  4. 'I needed to break some crazy cycles': How Warwick found peace living in a beach shack

    In a rough tin shack perched on perfect white sand, Warwick Thornton reclines on a daybed holding a chicken. It's not a bad way to spend the day, really.

Good News

  1. 'A magical experience': First snowfall of season expected to draw crowds to Barrington Tops

    The season's first flurry of snow has dusted Barrington Tops just in time for the start of winter, with accommodation providers hopeful the town will be full for the long weekend.

  2. Cat travels 2,500km after stowing away in neighbour's truck

    Thanks to the goodwill of strangers, P-Puss the tabby cat has returned home

  3. The humpbacks have arrived, so how do you whale-watch while social distancing?

    This year's annual migration may be a different experience for whale watchers, with COVID-19 social distancing restrictions meaning there could be fewer boats on the water.

  4. More people adopting pets during pandemic but screening also increases

    The coronavirus lockdown leads to a surge in pet adoptions, and the RSPCA is hopeful a new online booking and screening system will prevent a flood of abandoned pets once the crisis is over.

Health

  1. Aunty Lorraine is hungry to heal as many of her mob as possible

    She is a Stolen Generations survivor and her pioneering healing program is part of a groundswell of Indigenous-led solutions to address the trauma of the past.

  2. 'A dream come true': How the anti-vax movement is exploiting the coronavirus crisis

    As humanity waits impatiently for a coronavirus vaccine, a determined minority is exploiting the crisis to push the health debate in a different direction.

  3. 'There's no silver bullet': More than 200 drugs are tested in the search for a coronavirus treatment

    If you're feeling overwhelmed by the fast and furious pace of new studies coming out about coronavirus treatments you're not alone. We asked scientists about their views on the latest developments and what the future may look like.

  4. Where mainstream mental health approaches have failed, Indigenous-led programs are cutting through

    Forced removals of children from their families have brought trauma to generations of Indigenous communities. Today those communities are increasingly taking the lead on how to heal.

Rural

  1. Trouble on Condamine floodplain track in southern Queensland with review of new inland rail route ordered

    Construction of the $10 billion Melbourne-to-Brisbane rail line has started, but after 10 years and up to $20 million worth of work, debate is still raging about where it should go.

  2. Thousands of cattle hit outback Queensland stock routes to journey from Barcaldine to Roma

    It takes just 15 dogs, a handful of horses and three drovers to steer more than 2,000 cattle along the dusty stock routes of western Queensland. The three-month journey aims to save valuable pasture on graziers' properties.

  3. Agricultural show goes virtual in a radio first for locked-down communities

    A radio station hosts the first virtual agricultural show on air for communities where local events were cancelled.

  4. Dogs more vulnerable to snakebite than cats, owing to fast-clotting blood, research finds

    Fast blood clotting in dogs leaves them more at risk of succumbing to snake bite than other household pets, new research finds.
